awd_titl_txt: Mathematical Learning via Architectural Design and Modeling Using E-Rebuild
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will explore the learning of mathematics through architectural tasks in an online simulation game, E-Rebuild. There is a need to connect mathematics to real world contexts and problems. In the game-based architectural simulation, students will be able to complete tasks such as building and constructing structures while using mathematics and problem solving. The learning platform will be flexible so teachers can customize tasks for their students. The project will examine how to collect data about students' learning from data generated as they play the game. The project will explore how students learn mathematics using the simulation and how the simulation can be included in middle school mathematics learning. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

The project includes two major research questions. First, how will the design of a scalable game-based, design-centered learning platform promote coordination and application of math representation for problem solving? Second, how and under what implementation circumstances will using a scalable architectural game-based learning platform improve students multi-stranded mathematical proficiency (i.e., understanding, problem solving and positive disposition)? A key feature of the project is stealth-assessment or data collected and logged as students use the architectural simulation activities that can be used to understand their mathematics learning. The project uses a design-based research approach to gather data from students and teachers that will inform the design of the learning environment. The qualitative and quantitative data will also be used to understand what students are learning as they play the game and how teachers are interacting with their students. The project will include a mixed methods study to compare classrooms using the architectural activities to classrooms that are using typical activities.

por.por_cntn:
In this design-based research project, we have investigated whether and how participating in three-dimensional architectural design and modeling via a simulation game-based learning platform (called E-Rebuild) will support integrated math representation and active problem solving for middle school students. E-Rebuild frames mathematical representation and problem solving as a structured series of architectural design and problem-solving quests; allows for end-user customization of the learning tasks via a no-code game level editor; and incorporates unobtrusive diagnostic assessment as well as assessment-driven learner support during the course of game play. We have implemented and evaluated E-Rebuild in the middle school setting to examine the design heuristics and game-based pedagogy or activity structures that promote an effective and scalable application of digital game-based math learning for and by a diverse group of middle school students and teachers.

 

The key project outputs include:

  • An iteratively refined and tested game-based learning platform (E-Rebuild) that has presented promise in promoting math problem solving performance in three alternative school learning settings (in class, after-school program, and summer camp) for middle-school students, in either on-campus or remote (online) mode. There is a statically significant improvement of the E-Rebuild student participants from the pretest to the posttest of math problem solving; the game-based learning group have consistently outperformed the business-as-usual control group in the math problem-solving test performance, with a medium effect size.

  • An in-game evidence-centered, math-competency assessment model that leverages an interpretable Bayesian net model, enables a real-time tracking of CCSS (common core state standards) aligned math competency development, and drives learner-adaptive game task navigation and in-game learning support. The cross-validation accuracy of the current model is .70+ for predicting the root node (or the overall math competency).

  • A no-code game-level editor has been prototyped to support in-service teachers in reviewing and composing applied math problems. The findings with iterative teacher workshops and teaching experiments suggest that math task design-centered training activities help teachers to enact, reflect on, and refine their knowledge and epistemic perspectives for math teaching.

  • The heuristics governing the design of game-based learning supports. The study findings suggest a positive and predictive impact of using mathematizing supports on the logged and observed performance of applied math problem solving by students during and after gaming. Overall, the design of game-based mathematical experience and learning support have to balance and adapt the features of problematizing and structuring on and for individual students? task persistence, agency, and deductive reasoning development.

 

The E-Rebuild online game is shared with communities of interest via a publicly accessible project website (https://erebuild.coe.fsu.edu/). The project materials have been shared with teachers and researchers through teacher workshops, information seminars, and professional networks. The current project findings are continuously disseminated to communities of interest through multiple refereed journal publications, one monograph book, book chapters, and multiple refereed conference proceedings and presentations.
